game_setup: ^LONG_DISTANCE_VERBS look, walk, walk to, follow, throw at, shoot, photograph, scan, go back, go inside
exit_to_ship: ^GET THE PLAYER BACK TO THE SHIP SOMEHOW!!

first: ^>>>	The ship drifted along the winds of the Nebula.

s: ^El: 	How long till we reach Elboreth?
c: ^Six: 	Perhaps you would prefer to sleep?

s: ^El:		I'll stay awake for a while, I think.
c: ^El:		Might as well enjoy the peace and quiet while we have it.
^El: 	Where would I be without you?
^Six:	Still on the surface of Alberath, Mistress, with your leg trapped under a stone.

aboard_ship_to_iox: ^>>> I sat at the flight deck, boots up on the console.

robot_trustworthy: ^Six:	Mistress, can I bring you any refreshment?

c: ^>>> 	He rolled away, and the room seemed to expand. But he wouldn't be gone for long.

s: ^El:		Why don't you go and rest?
c: ^>>> 	Six isn't the first robot they've given me. But for some reason I trust this one less than the last.
^>>> 	I rely on his Ethical Core to pull me out of doing stupid things all the time.
^>>> 	What if one day Six doesn't pull me out? Am I certain that would never happen?

s: ^El:		We've had a few close calls recently.
c: ^Six:	But all have been within acceptable parameters.

s: ^El:		Do you think we're getting close to finding anything out here, Six?
c: ^Six:	We are constantly finding things, Mistress.
^Six:	I am not in a position to judge their value.

robot_trustworthy: ^>>> Six returned with a glass of water. I put it down on the console, untouched.
^Six:	We will need to refill the tank on Iox, Mistress.

g-0: ^>>> 	The Professor is right when she says I can't be trusted to look after myself.
^>>> 	But how much does Six tell them?

s: ^El:	 There are people in this Nebula who have no idea what's out here.
c: ^El:		People who've never set foot in space.
^Six:	When did you first sail, Mistress?
^El:		Early twenties, I suppose. I hired a skiff from Iox and took it the nearest belt.
^El:		I was going to find my first great find.
^El:		I drifted off the winds and ran out of fuel.
^Six:	That will not happen in my presence.

s: ^El:		I'm a better sailor now, Six.
^El:		No; I'd throw you overboard for thrust.
^El:		Thanks, Six, it's nice to know.

c: ^Six:	I will assume the worst, Mistress.

s: ^El:		The first time? I was young.
c: ^El:		Twelve years old, I think. I took a frigate to Iox.
^El:		I was sent to the university. They wanted to meet me.

s: ^El:		They wanted to give me a job. At twelve.
c: ^El:		I never stood a chance, really.
^El:		They wanted it, so they gave me a trip through space and asked me to hand it over.
^Six:	Mistress, I am just a robot.

s: ^El:		In a way, I suppose so.

c: ^El:		I don't want to think about it.

s: ^El:  	Do you ever look at it, Six? This Nebula of ours.
c: ^Six:	I have seen it often enough.
^Six: 	Hardly, Mistress. I do not understand the question.

s: ^El: 	But what do you make of it?
c: ^Six: 	I do not think I understand the question, Mistress.

s: ^El:		What does it hide, do you suppose?
^El:		... the shape. The structure. All these scattered rocks, planets.
c: ^El:		All thrown together like pots in a bazaar.

s: ^El:		... good enough, to me. I would expect the creator to do better.
^El:		... the most elegant of designs for a universe.

g-0: ^Six: 	I do not believe I my opinion counts on the matter, Mistress.

s: ^El:		... it just seems like a strange way for the universe to be.
c: ^El:		If I were to believe in a creator, I would want one that was better organised.

s: ^El:		... you see lines of force, and nothing more than that.

believeforce: ^Six:	I understand that the Nebula is organised by basic principles of gravity and ether flow.

c: ^Six:	The attraction of matter to other matter.

s: ^El:		But what is ether flow, exactly?
c: ^Six: 	The movement of space within the Cloud, Mistress.

s: ^El:		But what if there's more to it?
c: ^Six: 	I cannot see how. Both gravity and ether are well-understood, Mistress.
^Six: 	They have no more meaning than the way that water can freeze.

s: ^El:		Then why is it such a state?

g-1: ^Six: 	But I suspect I have missed your meaning.

s: ^El: 	There's a dream I often have...
c: ^El:		Of a single planet, going around a Sun.

s: ^El:		It's not only me. Others have it.
c: ^Six: 	Does it come from a story?

s: ^El:		I suppose so. I don't know where I first heard it.
^El:		Every story is a reflection of some need.

g-0: ^Six:	The Nebula is a most complex environment, certainly.

s: ^El:		It's a dream of a tidier place. This one is too messy.
^El:		... it's easy to assume that everything has meaning.
c: ^El:		As though all these rocks and stones must have been placed by someone, for a reason.

s: ^El:		... what do you suppose is out there?
c: ^El: 	Or have we seen it all?
^Six: 	The Nebula is large, Mistress, but well connected. I believe most of its secrets have been unearthed.

s: ^El: 	You do? Then what's the point in what we do?
^El:		That's a poor way to live.
c: ^Six: 	I am a machine, Mistress. My parameters are quite well-defined.
^El:		Even your previous Ethical Core seems to be constantly open for reinterpretation.

observed: ^Six: 	I have observed, Mistress, that the complexity always arises from small details.
^Six: 	Take my construction, for example, Mistress. My basic functions are quite basic.
^Six: 	But the complexity in moving fluid from one part of my body to another; that requires great tangles of cables.

s: ^El: 	So you think it's just a matter of minor details?
c: ^El:		Little things, that make the whole Nebula splatter outwards like a dropped box of rice?

s: ^El:		I'm sorry, Six, you're simply poorly built.
c: ^Six:	Whereas I doubt the Nebula even had an architect, Mistress.

s: ^El: 	Don't let anyone on Iox hear you say that.

b: ^Six:	The Ancestors, Mistress. Where did they go?
^Six:	Mistress, if I may ask a question.

g-0: ^El:		They lived all across the Nebula, on all the smaller planetoids.

s: ^El:		Several of these sites are unexplored. They may still be here.
c: ^Six:	You cannot believe that, Mistress. There is no sign anywhere. No ships. No lights.

s: ^El:		The sites are full of temples promising "ascension".
c: ^El:		Perhaps that's where they went, in the end?

s: ^El:		They moved off the asteroids, and onto the planets.
c: ^El:		They're us. Well, not you, of course.
^El:		And wherever they went... are we heading there too?

whatever_happened_to_five: ^Six:	Mistress? What did happen to Five?

s: ^El: 	Do you know the first Principle of Action?
c: ^El:		If you throw something in space, then you are pushed back the other way?
^Six: 	Do I understand you used my predecessor as ballast, Mistress?
^Six:	Ah, so Five's Ethical Core prompted him to throw himself off the ship?

s: ^El:		Wasn't the only thing I had aboard, either.
^El:		Six, why do you have to have that face?
c: ^Six:	I do not understand the question, Mistress.

s: ^El:		You could have any face you like.
c: ^El:		It's not real. Why that one?
^Six:	My face is part of me, Mistress. It was uniquely created when I was built.

s: ^El:		I don't like it. I don't like your face.

g-1: ^Six:	I apologise if my face displeases you, Mistress. I fear I am unable to alter it.

c: ^El:		Is it based on a person?

s: ^El:		Shouldn't I be able to change it? To get what I want?
c: ^Six:	I believe it is disallowed to prevent the substitution of one robot for another.

g-2: ^Six:	I believe it is based on various minor variables that can be adjusted to provide a range of results.

s: ^El:		So why does your face look like my ex-husband?
c: ^Six:	Was your husband in an accident, Mistress?

s: ^El:		Yes, but not the way you mean.
^El:		I'm not going to talk about it to you.

g-0: ^Six:	I fear I have mis-spoken, Mistress. I will withdraw from this conversation to allow you to restore your emotional equilibrium.

s: ^El:		I'm fine, I don't need to restore anything.
^El:		Well, I don't like it. Can't you turn it off?
c: ^Six:	It is believed that the presence of a face ensures a better connection between robot and owner.

s: ^El:	But that face. It can't be a coincidence.
c: ^El:		The Professor must have picked it because it looked liked my ex-husband.

fear_done_something: ^Six:	Mistress? Have I angered you in some way?
^Six:	I fear our relationship is not entirely cordial.

c: ^El:		The world is a tough place sometimes,
^Six: 	You mean, there is nothing I can do to alter the situation.

s: ^El:	... but I shouldn't take it out on you.
^El:	... and I didn't ask to have you with me.
c: ^Six:	I did not ask for the assignment.

s: ^El:		No matter. Forget I mentioned it.
^El:		You're not the first robot I've had tailing me.
c: ^El:		I'll get rid of you in the end.

s: ^El:		And why is that, I wonder?
c: ^Six: 	Mistress? It is in my programming.

s: ^El:		We must do something about that.
^El:	But Six, they keep on giving me robots.
c: ^El:	Every time I break or lose one, they give me another.

s: ^El:	... They must take my safety very seriously.
^El:	... It's like they're trying to get rid of them.

g-0: ^Six:	They care for your well-being, Mistress.

spying: ^Six: 	And of course, I provide more accurate expedition reports than you might compile.

c: ^El:		No one else at the university is stupid enough to do what I do.

b: ^El:		They need me in one piece for that stupidy, I suppose.
^El:		They'd be stuck if they lost me.

c: ^Six:	I consider myself a research assistant, Mistress.

b: ^El:	You're never going to rise to greatness, are you?
^El:	I can't have an embarrassing affair with you, can I?

s: ^El:		Or are you just copying what I do?
^El:		Do you really want to research?

g-0: ^Six:	I gain pleasure from understanding, Mistress.
^Six: 	That makes me well-suited to research.
^Six:	If such action assists you, Mistress, then I understand.
^Six:	But thank you for your explanation.
^El:		But you limit me at every turn.
^Six:	Mistress, I have saved your life repeatedly.

g-1: ^Six:	And I provide valuable scanning and recording information.
^Six:	Not to mention, I also carry your brushes.

s: ^El:		I'm not going to apologise to a robot.
c: ^El:		So you'd better get used to it.

s: ^El:		So you're a scanner in a hip-bag.
c: ^Six: 	And a guardian and a protector, Mistress.

s: ^El: 	Anyway. Let's see if you and I can do better.
c: ^Six:	Thank you, Mistress. I would appreciate that.

metal_connector: ^El: 	A small, metal container, almost like a socket.
paper_about_el: ^El: 	Let's see what this things says.

intro: ^The vastness of space. The ship slowly sails forward. El talks in v/o.
introlines1: ^>>>		A pool of worlds, bound together by swirling winds.
introlines2: ^>>> 	An uneasy, divided place - the larger worlds ruling over a hundred scattered fiefdoms, without enough resources to go round.
^>>>		Ships ply the trade-winds, but piracy is commonplace. The law on one world is outrage on an another.
introlines3: ^>>>		It was not always like this. Once, the Nebula was an Empire, that reached from Iox to Elboreth and beyond.
^>>>		Once, great ships sailed as far as the Outer Reach.
^>>>		There are tiny stars in the sky there now, that shine with unnatural light, beyond the winds.
main: ^Camera pulls back into the flight deck of the ship. El and Six sit, glued to the viewport.
^Six:	Do you want me to land?

c: ^Six:	It has been growing stronger as we approach.
^Six:	Mostly attendant buildings on the central temple.
^Six: 	My apologies, but my Ethical Core will not allow that.

s: ^El:		Have I still not turned that off?
c: ^Six: 	It would kill me if you tried.

s: ^El:		The fault of my own Ethical Core, then.

c: ^Six: 	Please, Mistress. I do not like to contemplate my own termination.
^Six: 	I shall take that as an agreement that I should do the landing.

s: ^El:		You can consider it a threat, if you like.
c: ^Six: 	I have always found your humour to be deficient, Mistress.
^Six: 	I will now land the ship.

g-0: ^Six: 	 Please excuse me for a minute.

top: ^The background slowly moves into focus. A spaceship berth. A robot face looms into view, but we do not see his body.

c: ^Six:	I fear you did not escape the rubble of the collapsing ruins quite as I had hoped.
^Six: 	Indeed. They are now somewhat *more* ruined, I am afraid.

g-0: ^Six: 	I was forced to activate the hopper.

c: ^Six: 	Thankfully no, Mistress. That was avoided by moments.
^Six:	Indeed. It has most likely left you dehydrated.

s: ^El:		Just tell me what happened down there.
^El:		What's going on? Where am I?

g-1: ^Six:	Please wait here while I get you some water.
^The robot hoves out of view. El sits up.

c: ^>>> I put a hand to the side of my head and winced.
^El: 	There's a bump coming, all right.
^El:		I know this place all right.
^El:		There must be sandgrubs in here by now.
^Head: 	I do not understand the question.
^El:: 	Found in the ruins at Makhesh. I still have no idea why it understands me.

g-0: ^Head: 	I do not understand the question.
^El:: 	Perhaps it doesn't understand me after all.

c: ^El:	Looks like I left my mark.

b: ^Six: 	It is good to see you recovered, Mistress. I was not sure you would, considering.

c: ^Six: 	I will endeavour to remind you, Mistress.

six_returns: ^Six returns to the room, carrying a glass of water.

c: ^El:		Have you been using the reclaimed water tank again?

g-1: ^Six:	I have been forced used to broach the reclaimed water tank, Mistress.
^Six:	I suggest we return to Elboreth soon.

c: ^Six:	I see the hopper's effect on your short-term memory has been particularly acute this time.

s: ^El:		How long is the return journey?
c: ^Six:	We should be there by evening if we leave immediately.

running_down_tunnel1: ^El is running down a stone corridor. Six is nowhere to be seen.

c: ^El: 	There's a mark on the wall there. Did I see that earlier?

running_down_tunnel3: ^El looks back over her shoulder. Whatever is coming is still coming.

c: ^The passage behind is willing with a wall of sand...

s: ^El:	This place will fall apart any moment.

outside: ^El explodes from the cavern mouth, almost tripping over a large metal box on the ground.

g-1: ^Six unfolds - he is the box. Finally, the head materialises.

s: ^El:	 Look at me! What do you think?

g-3: ^A dark wave erupts from the cavern mouth...

NPC: ^Six: 	The ship appears to be in good working order, Mistress.

s: ^El: 	Not affected by whatever was going on below?
c: ^Six:	Not in any way I am aware of, no.
^El:	This is the best ship I could afford when I left Iox, and it's done me well enough so far.
^El::	We're not so far from Elboreth here.
^Six:	Can you pick out home, Mistress?
^Six:	I am sure the navigation computer will locate Elboreth successfully.

s: ^El:		I'll find my way by feel.

considering: ^Six: 	Considering the viewport as a normalised grid with upper-left origin, Elboreth lies at coordinates...
^Six: 	It's somewhere to our left, Mistress.

c: ^El:		All right, Six. Let's go home.

iox_scene: ^The plaza of the University of Iox, which sprawls across an enormous portion of this planet. It is laid out like a Roman villa; clean, with gardens and fountains. Starmaps adorn the walls and the buildings are domed, decorated with swirl-like representations of the winds.

intro: ^>>> Iox. Home of the University, the Council, and the wealthy.
^>>> Most Oxers don't ever leave. They wait for the Delta to come to them.

c: ^El: 	People on Elboreth just don't know that a life like this is possible.
^Six:	There are a lot more people on Elboreth than here.
^El:		But even that seems the wrong way up.

b: ^El:	There's never enough to go around.

g-1: ^Six:	Ah. It is good to be home.

c: ^Six:	You are well of my capacity for feelings, Mistress.
^Six:	It may not be your home, Mistress.

s: ^El:		You feel like that, do you?
^El:		I didn't know you had feelings.

prob: ^Six: The probability of harm is particularly low here.

c: ^>>> The great Library of Iox holds a copy of every book we have. It's still only a single room.
^El:		Professor Myari's office is in there.
^El:		Let's go and see if the Professor is in.

b: ^Lex:	Thanks for coming so quickly. A safe flight?
^Lex:	Glad you finally decided to turn up.

s: ^El:		I didn't blow anything up, if that's what you mean.
c: ^Lex:	That's what I mean. I'm glad to hear it.

s: ^El:		Don't treat me like an idiot.
c: ^Lex:	I'll stop treating you like an idiot when you stop acting like one.

s: ^El:		Guilty until proven innocent, I see.
^El:		Professor, what happened on that asteroid wasn't my fault.
c: ^Lex:	You may be right. I hope you are.

g-1: ^Lex: 	And how are you, Six? Fully functional, I hope?

s: ^El:		I've not done anything to Six.
c: ^Lex:	You'll forgive me if I'm not confident of that.
^Lex:	I remember what happened to Three.
^Lex:	The damn thing was speaking backwards by the time you finished with it.

s: ^El:		Six and I have been getting on well.
c: ^Lex:	So you've not broken it, dropped it down a hole, or scrambled its brain yet?
^Lex:	Watch yourself, Six. This one has a thing against robots.

g-2: ^>>> She moved off to her office.

intro: ^The grand library of Iox is a wide dome filled with a gentle hush.

b: ^a man is a reading a book

c: ^Six:	Do you intend to be inside here for very long?

s: ^El:		Perhaps, if I find anything interesting.

g-0: ^Six:	It is very dark. I might require to leave to recharge.

s: ^El:		All right. But stay close if you go.

c: ^El:		This place has all the books in the Delta.
^El:		At least, as far as anyone knows.

b: ^Six:	I observe you do not seem bound by the convention of silence yourself, I observe.
^El::	 	Nothing else is jumping out at me.

c: ^>>> Six whizzed through the book while I waited.
^>>> I paced back away from the shelves while Six read.

b: ^>>> Huang looked up, caught sight of the book, and nodded to himself.
^>>> Then he looked down once more.
^El::	It seems to be mostly stuff I know.
^El:: 	Wellsprings are the source of all the water in the Delta.
^El:: 	It pours out, and is whipped out into space, where it freezes.
^El::	Looks like the author think the wells are fed from the starlight itself.
^El::	Seems like a nothing kind of a planet.
^El::	Farms. Important, once, but long ago.
^El::	Not obvious why Huang even went there.

six_offers_to_read: ^Six: 	Would you like me to read it for you, Mistress?
huang_snark_six_reads: ^Huang: 	You let him read for you, do you?

c: ^Huang:	You're sure of that, I see.
^Huang:	Books are the only thing we have.

six_is_reading_tick: ^>>> Six whizzed through the pages of the book.
six_finishes_book: ^Six: 	I have finished, Mistress. Would you like a summary?

c: ^El:		Just update our ship when we get back.

hyaf_book: ^Six:	It is a brief and rather vague history of the Hyaf farming moon.
^Six: 	It seems to have been flourishing at one time and was considered to be of strategic importance during the rebellions.

c: ^Six:	It seems the population there has been quite steady, and the settlement has been widely forgotten.

wellspring_book: ^Six:	A rather tedious outline of the dynamics of a wellspring, Mistress.
^Six:	The writer has studied a few wells to try and understand their rates of flow.

s: ^El:		What's so complicated about a well?
c: ^Six:	When one finds something, it is natural to question where that thing comes from.
^Six:	He argues that the water from the wellsprings must come from somewhere.

s: ^El:		So where does it come from?
c: ^Six:	He suggests it disperses into the starlight, flows over the edges of the Delta, and is from there somehow fed back to the springs.
^Six:	He presents little evidence for this conclusion.
^Six:	It seems the wells cease to flow at night, and resume once the sun has risen.
^Huang:	You really do sail the Delta on your own, don't you?

produced_locket: ^>>> Huang put down his book, and reached into a padded box to pull something out. A locket.
^>>> He put in on the table beside him.
snark_about_hyaf_book: ^Huang: Is that book what I think it is?
^Huang: If I told you about a mythical moon whose rainfall is made from finest silk, would you go looking for it?

c: ^Huang: 	Well, perhaps one day I'll put it to the test.
^Huang: 	Hyaf is real, at least. Even if it is mostly mud.
^Huang: 	It's more responsibility than I'm used to.

s: ^El:		Is it an interesting place, or isn't it?

b: ^Huang:	As far as I know, this little trinket is the only artefact from there.

puts_locket_away: ^>>> With that, he lifted the locket up, and folded it and the chain carefully into his pocket.

c: ^El:: Huang Xe; I've met him a couple of times. He's one of the Professor's protegés. She likes her protegés old.
^>>> Huang looked up, and nodded, then returned to his book.
^Huang: 	I'll remember that, for when we next have a conversation.
^Huang:	And you thought you'd do it noisily in the library?

s: ^El:		I'm talking to you, aren't I?
^El:		I think I heard the Professor calling you.
^El:		What time are you leaving here?

c: ^Huang:	You have something of a reputation, you know.

s: ^El:		I wondered if you wanted to go somewhere and talk.
c: ^El:		You're not really meant to talk in a library.
^Huang:	Well, I'm sure your ship is just a hop away.
^Huang:	Not enough to steal, if that's what you were thinking.
^Huang:	I've not seen many like it, no.

what_do_you_want: ^Huang: 	Now what do you want, I wonder?

b: ^Huang:	I've never known you to pass a compliment for free.

c: ^Huang: Just concerend for my safety, are you?

s: ^El:	I'm not sure what you're implying.

howyoupay: ^Huang:	We all know how you archaeologists pay for your ships, Doctor Ikrai.

c: ^Huang: 	Oh, yes. I forgot, you're a woman of honour.

s: ^El:	We do the work to dig the things up, you know.
^El:		I hate to think how you pay for things, Huang.
^El:		I'm just saying it suits you.
^El:	Where did you get it from?
c: ^Huang:	I suppose there's no harm in telling you.
^Huang:	Do you know Hyaf? Small moon, about halfway out.

s: ^El:		There are a lot of moons out there.
c: ^Huang:	We're all moons in the Delta, as they say.

g-0: ^Huang:	It's a fairly unremarkable farming community.
^Huang:	 I was there, oh, twelve years ago now.

c: ^Huang:	It's built on the ruins of a

s: ^El:		What kind of archaeologist would I be if I didn't?
c: ^Huang:	So you don't know about wellsprings, then?  Well, no matter.
^Huang:	The temple above the well has collapsed, yes. But the water still flows.
^Huang:	Or at any rate, it did.
^Huang:	In some ways, perhaps. But compared to this place...
^Huang:	They get by out there, I suppose.

lex_and_robots: ^Lex:	Do you know where the robots we give you come from, Elesira?

c: ^Lex:	Have you ever seen a robot manufacturer?

s: ^El:		I don't have the freedom of Iox the way you do.
c: ^Lex: 	There are repair shops out there, but not manufacturers.

s: ^El:		I knew it. The robot is a spy for someone else.
c: ^Lex:	What? No. I mean, do you know where the robots really come from?

g-0: ^Lex:	No one makes the robots. We found them.

c: ^Lex:	Eventually, yes. But no one alive today.

g-1: ^Lex: 	We were doing scans from the sky of Iox looking for finds.
^Lex:	There's a lot of important sites on Iox, all much more interesting than what's out there in the belt.
^Lex:	And we found this long trench that the scans said was full of artefacts.

c: ^Lex:	Come on, woman, you're an archaeologist.

g-2: ^Lex:	We began a dig. With as much secrecy as we could. I was heading it up.
^Lex:	The trench was actually a long, metal cavern, set at an angle into the earth.

c: ^Lex:	That was what I thought initially.
^Lex:	Exactly. You're ahead of me already.

g-3: ^Lex: 	We went inside, and that was where we found them. Rows and rows and rows of these machines.
^Lex:	They had no power, but once we took them outside the sunlight began to charge them.

c: ^Lex:	Every robot you see is one of these.
^Lex:	There were a thousand robots in the container, Elesira.

g-4: ^Lex:	That's all the robots we have, Elesira. Five were taken apart from study. The rest were spread out across various departments for use.

s: ^El:		And you've never found any more?
c: ^Lex:	Not as far as I've been told.

s: ^El:		So who made them? The Ancestors.
^El:		Do the robots remember anything? From before?
c: ^Lex:	No. Either their memories decayed over time, or they were new.

g-5: ^Lex:	Anyway, Elesira, I want to stress this to you very clearly.
^Lex:	You have got to stop breaking them.

s: ^El:		We've not been to Fenris before, have we?

c: ^El:		This place isn't very nice.  It's not very nice at all.

s: ^El:		Just keep your eyes to yourself.
^El:		They sell things here that other people wouldn't sell.
^El:		Don't say I didn't warn you.
^El:		I'm afraid your Ethical Core is in for a beating.

enter: ^An open market place. Several men and women are loitering under canopies, shaded from the sun. A large woman strides back and forth, calling out prices.

s: ^El: 	Don't worry about it, we aren't staying.
^El:		Just keep your head down, Six.

c: ^El: 	This is Fenris. It's about as far from Iox as you can go.
^Six: 	But knowing something and witnessing it have different effects on my programming.

s: ^El:		Just ignore your programming and let's keep moving.
c: ^Six:	But I will attempt to move on.
^Six:	Have you been here before, Mistress?

s: ^El:		Let's not talk about it, Six.
^El:		They buy and sell people, Six, not machines.
c: ^Six: 	I am not concerned for myself.
^Six:	My Ethical Core is programmed against human suffering. It does not differentiate by economic status.

s: ^El:		Then your ethical core is broken.
c: ^Six:	I fear, Mistress, it is the only one I have.

s: ^El:		There's nothing you can do, Six.
c: ^Six:	I fear I am compelled to spend a considerable number of cycles verifying that before I can accept it, Mistress.

s: ^El:		Let's just keep moving and try not attract too much attention.

c: ^El:		I wish I could fix it for you, I really do.

b: ^Six:	Will this trade end one day, Mistress?

NPC: ^Six: What is our purpose here, Mistress?

b: ^Six: We are not purchasing, I hope.

s: ^El: 	There's someone here I'd like you to meet.

well_treated: ^Six: 	Do you believe they are well-treated, Mistress?

c: ^Six:	You are lying, Mistress, but I appreciate your consideration.

s: ^El:		It's not for your benefit, Six.
c: ^El:		My own Ethical Core doesn't do so well with this place either.

s: ^El:		One day, this will change, Six. It has to.

c: ^El:		But I feel it has to.
^Six: 	I cannot believe things, Mistress. I can only compute probabilities. But here...

s: ^El:		Slaves always overthrow their masters in the end.

g-0: ^Six: 	The error margins are too large. There is not enough data.

s: ^El: 	That's when you have to believe.
^El:		There is only one fact that matters.
c: ^El:		No one wants this place to exist. Not even those who profit from it.

s: ^El:		Nothing stays the same, Six. Nothing.

c: ^Six: 	Why do they not fight back?

s: ^El:		There's only so far you can run when you've got a chain around your ankles.
^El:		Some do. I doubt they get far.

g-0: ^Six: 	And how do the traders function?
^Six: 	How are they able to do this?

c: ^El: 	You can't fix a broken planet, or out-think it.
^El: 	But it's not an oversight. They know what they're doing.

s: ^El:		The money. They trade others powerlessness for their own power.

c: ^>>> The trader slumped on her chair with a fan, eyeing the crowd like a hungry bird.

top: ^>>> The trader roused herself, stepping down from her stand to block our path.

c: ^Trader: I wouldn't take your robot if you gave it to me for nothing. Why would I?

s: ^El:		Happy to treat people like machines instead?
c: ^Trader: I'm just another employer. While these things...

s: ^El:		Then we have nothing to discuss.

g-0: ^Trader: 	Who are you to bring a mechanical here?
^>>>	The trader poked Six in the eye.
^Trader: 	What good are these to anyone?

s: ^El:		I'd rather my servant wasn't a person.
^El:		I don't want argument with you.
c: ^Trader: 	Then get off my planet and take that thing of yours with you.
^El:		But believe me, I won't stay a moment longer than necessary.
^Trader: 	Be sure that you do not.

s: ^El:		Peace, trader. We'll be gone soon enough.

c: ^El: 	Did someone cut out your heart when you were a baby?

ha: ^Trader: 	I suppose you think that thing of yours will stop anyone from demanding a little more respect.

s: ^El:			The only respect you deserve is my spit in your eye.
c: ^Trader: 	Look, dog. This is my job. My profession. My mother did it, her father before her.
^Trader: 	It's how I put food on my table.
^Trader: 	Then watch what you bring onto our planet.

s: ^El:			Don't you have a shop to run?

yourkind: ^Trader: Your kind won't be happy until everyone in these clouds is starving and only the machines get to eat.

s: ^El:		If you go out of business, I won't shed a tear.
c: ^El:		And neither will those people you have in chains.

s: ^El: 	It won't be robots that stick a knife in your belly.
^El:		You don't look underfed to me.

b: ^El: Now get out of my way.
^Trader: 	I won't forget your face, friend.

g-1: ^>>> The trader stepped aside, clambering back to their place.

s: ^El:		We'll be off this rock soon.

g-0: ^Six:	What does the owner of this establishment do?

c: ^El:		If you mean shop, say shop.

s: ^El:	Sells and repairs things. Mechanicals, mostly.

g-1: ^Six:	Is this a shop? Is this junk for sale?

c: ^Six:	A little sand might improve the decor.
^Six:	I do not like this planet, Mistress.
^Six:	And I do not like this 'shop'.

s: ^El:	What did you think we were doing here?

b: ^Six: You are hardly in the habit of explaining your projects to me, Mistress.
^Six:	I am still gathering data for my hypothesis, Mistress.

amauld_chat: ^Amauld: Glad to hear you're in one piece, however.

c: ^Amauld:		You should be careful out there.
^El:		Amauld makes all sorts of toys.
^Toy: 	You shouldn't talk about people like they're things.
^Toy:	Come over here and say that.

s: ^El:		Amauld, come out from behind the curtain.

g-0: ^Toy:	Amauld says, go away big nose.

c: ^Amauld:	Nothing much. These are mostly half-ideas.

b: ^>>> I hit the buzzer again impatiently. From the backroom I heard a curse.

c: ^>>> The bell makes a nasty buzzing sound. There is a clattering from the backroom.

first: ^>>> Finally, a man appeared from the back room, wiping his hands on an oil-stained cloth.
^Amauld: What do you want? Oh - it's you.
^>>> Amauld and I are old friends.

g-0: ^Amauld: Are you here to sell me another broken scanner, like last time?

s: ^El:		I didn't know it was broken.
c: ^>>> 	I did, of course. I was five duckets short on a new sail.

s: ^El:		I don't have anything to sell you.

c: ^Amauld: Oh, don't you? Ripping people off just doesn't stick?

g-1: ^>>> We're old friends, after a fashion.

repeat: ^>>> Amauld finally emerged from the back room.

b: ^Amauld: Elesira. What can I do for you?
^Toy: 	Don't let the door hit you too hard as you go.
^Amauld:	Hush, Machellio. She's a good customer, in her way.

s: ^El:		Have you heard any rumours about unknown sites?
c: ^Amauld: I'm an engineer, not a guide.

intro: ^§ El and Six stand on a dusty street on the low-rent planet of Elboreth. A grimy tunnel mouth leads down towards underground apartments; a few other shops are visible including the Blue Monkey bar.
^>>> I shouldn't be living on a planet like this, so the Professor says.
^>>> She lives in a tower-room on Iox with a view across the Clouds.
^>>> My place is not like that.

c: ^>>> 	My friend Timor runs the Blue Monkey, a trading and drinking spot.
^El: 	Let's go see if there's anyone about.
^>>> 	This place isn't great but the people here don't seem to realise.
^>>> 	The local greeting is a slap on the back.
^>>>		It's like they're saying, "Well done! You lasted another day!"
^>>> 	Surface space is at a premium, so most dwellings are underground.
^>>> 	They pipe in the air room by room, so you can smell everyone above you.

s: ^El:	 	I want to look around a little first.
c: ^Six:	I will take the opportunity to gather some solar energy.
^§ Six lifts his head as though turning his face to the sun.

s: ^El:		We'll have plenty to do in the morning.
^El:		Might as well get some rest.
^El:		But I need a drink first.

g-1: ^Six:  	Mistress? Do you wish me to locate a purchaser for our lesser artefacts?
^Six: 	I am picking up some vendor beacons.

c: ^El:		It's not good for my reputation, selling these things on.
^El:		It lies in the dirt for four thousand years, and then I just fence them.

g-2: ^Six:	I would suggest these artefacts bring more happiness once sold.

s: ^El:		To the person who buys them, only.
^El:		Surely they belong in a museum.
c: ^Six:	The university museum currently contains over fifteen hundred similar rings, Mistress.

s: ^El:		So they don't pay as well.
^El:		That's fifteen hundred times someone didn't fence a ring.
c: ^Six:	I wonder how many times they did?

intro: ^§ El and Six roll into the Blue Monkey.
greeting1: ^Timor: 	Welcome back. Still in one piece?

c: ^Timor:	Sit down, have a drink. First one is on the house.
^Timor:	Maybe not, but I need your custom. Sit down, El.

s1: ^Timor:	Evening, El. Sit anywhere you like.

c: ^El:	I've got a few pieces for you to look at, Timor.
^El:: Photographs of his children. They're all long gone now, of course.
^Timor:	People are feeling uncomfortable with the elections coming, I think. Aren't you?

s: ^El:		If things go bad, I'll move to Iox.
c: ^Timor:	They won't have you on Iox and you know it, El.

s: ^El:		If you talk this that, no wonder people don't drink here.
c: ^Timor:	Ha. You might well be right about that.
^Timor: 	Coming right up. I've got a fresh plant in the deep-freeze.
^Timor: 	I've got a nice bottle from Escara I've been saving...
^Timor: 	I would love to, but when the last time we had gin?
^Timor: 	Ah, you've been on a ship for a few weeks. I'll open a fresh bottle for you.

s: ^El:		Nothing, but I've got a few things for you.

c: ^Timor: 	That kind of day? Whatever you say.

b: ^Timor: 	I'll get you something cheap with a burn to it.

c: ^El:		I could use something to pick me up a little.

b: ^El:		If I knew how to mix a decent Sunflower, do you think I'd come here?
^El:		It belongs to whoever pays for it, for as long as they can keep it.
^Timor: 	Everyone knows everything in the end.

c: ^Timor: 	But you'd have to come up with some other excuse.

s: ^El: 	Things aren't right at the university.
c: ^Timor:	But it's how you choose to act that matters.

b: ^El: That must be why I like you.
^El:	I always wondered if I'd meet one.

c: ^El:		But nothing major. Not what's waiting.

s: ^El:		Do you have any idea how large the Cloud is, Timor?
c: ^El:		There are a thousand tiny worlds. There's so much to learn.
^Timor:	Ah, I see, as simple as that.

s: ^El:		I don't know. There are so many questions to answer.

totemple: ^Timor: 	I went to the Loop Temple last week. It wasn't so bad.

c: ^ is the worst kind of half-think.

s: ^El:		I thought better of you, Timor.
c: ^Timor:	Not all of us are as strong-minded as you, Aqila.
^Timor: 	You could see look into the stars and call space dark. You're a lion.
^El:		It's what my name means. It's a bird from Maxiil.
^Timor: 	I'd run and hide if you did.

s: ^El: 	I'm a footsore archaeologist, nothing more.
c: ^Timor:	The Temple isn't so bad, you know.

g-0: ^Timor: 	You should come and hear them out sometime. We could go together.

c: ^Timor: 	I'm trying to help you, Aqila. I see you're not happy.

s: ^El:		What they teach at Temple goes against everything I believe.
c: ^El:		I don't think it would help.
^Timor: 	No pressure. I'll keep serving you whatever you decide.

NPC: ^Timor: 	I'm running low on things to sell, by the way.
^Timor:	In case you've got any pieces you don't need.

s: ^El:		I'll show you what I've got.
^El: Come on, Timor. I don't sell my finds.

c: ^El:		There's more out there to explore.
^El:		But the university doesn't pay me to drink your Sunflowers.

b: ^Timor:	I had a letter from Rashid last week.
^Timor:	I had a letter from Rashid not long ago.

c: ^Timor: 	A real letter, the silly boy.

g-0: ^Timor: 	All his news, but by the time it reached me it was already out of date, of course.

c: ^Timor: 	You don't have children, do you?

g-0: ^Timor:	In this whole system there's nothing like it.
^Timor:	It's like someone glued your hands to a wild horse and then gave it a kick.

c: ^Timor:	He's on Fenris. It's a slow ship to get there. I looked into it once.
^Timor:	I couldn't ask you to do that.

s: ^El:		Why not? I go out almost every day.
^El:		You could, if you wanted to.
^El:		I think you're afraid to leave your bar.
^El:		You should do it one day.
^El:		It'll take a day at the most.

g-0: ^Timor:	I'm not sure Rashid wants to see me. And I don't know how I'd find him.

c: ^Timor:	Are you joking? Why would he do that?
^Timor:	If you got out of this hole would you come back?
^Timor:	Then you're mad, Elesira. There's nothing here worth coming back for.

s: ^El:		Where else is there to go?
c: ^Timor:	Iox. I hear they have gardens the size of cities on Iox.
^Timor: 	I hear they spend every weekend dancing.

s: ^El:	So how is your son doing?
c: ^Timor:	Who knows? He says he's happy enough, but he doesn't want to talk to his father.
^Timor:	Oh, to get away from his father's advice, I suppose.
^Timor:	More likely he was following a woman.
^Timor: 	He always was a foolish boy.

g-0: ^Timor:	Oh, well. Wherever he is, I hope he is happy.

s: ^El:	Your son, Rashid. Where is he?

at: ^§ 	 A long tunnel, lit by a lightcables strung along the walls. Doors lead off here and there.

s: ^El:	I'm not sleeping with you inside the room.
^El: 	You might as well come in.

s0: ^El: 	Don't want anyone walking off with you.

b: ^>>> Six took up position outside the door.

intro: ^El's room. Potentially nothing to do here, story-wise, might simply be a UI/pacing thing, depending on how the flow works.
^Broadly, this is the end of the tutorial / intro section, and should start opening out a bit

c: ^Six:	There are not many explorers of these asteroids.

b: ^Six:	I aim for truthfulness, Mistress, nothing less.
^Six:	I apologise for any offence, Mistress.

s: ^El:		And most work for this lot.
c: ^Six:	They seem a most substantial operation.

s: ^El:		We'd be well-funded, for once. A good ship.
c: ^Six:	You might be required to work in a team.

s: ^El:		I wouldn't have the freedom the university gives me.
^El:		I wonder how they make their money?

sleep: ^§ Do whatever transition we do for night time.

message_from_iox_re_alberthath: ^Six:	 Good morning, Mistress. I have a communication from Professor Myari.

c: ^>>> I splashed my face a little.

s: ^El:		What can I do for you?
^El:		If this is about the asteroid yesterday...

g-1: ^Six:	I don't suppose you've launched already this morning?

g-2: ^Six:	That planetoid you visited yesterday. Your great discovery.

s: ^El:		We landed, and set off some kind of system.
c: ^El:		The asteroid came apart. We barely escaped.
^Six:	Look, I'm glad you're intact. Both of you.

g-3: ^Six:	As of this morning, that asteroid is gone.

s: ^El:		It was falling to pieces when we left.
c: ^El:		I suppose it must have collapsed.
^Six:	When things collapse, they don't vanish.
^El:		Maybe they carried the pieces away.
^Six:	Most rocks don't have lightsails, do they?

s: ^El:		Do you want me to go and have a look?

g-5: ^Six:	I want you to come to Iox. More to the point, I want Six to come.
^Six:	I want to see exactly what you did.

s: ^El:	I have somewhere else I should be.
c: ^Six:	We pay for your apartment, Ms Elassar. Be here.

s: ^El:		I'll head over once I'm up.
^El:		I could go and have a look.
c: ^Six:	All the interesting material is in your robot. So bring it here, please.
^Six:	Don't blow up anything else on the way.
^>>>	I gestured for Six to cut the connection, which he did.

g-7: ^Six: 	Mistress? Will we be heading to Iox?

reflect_on_alberthath: ^>>> I stretched out on the bed, and sighed.

s: ^El:		We'll have to go back to that little planet, Six.
c: ^Six:	Yes, Mistress, though I fear whatever was there will have been destroyed.

s: ^El:		We didn't destroyed the entire asteroid.
c: ^Six:	No, Mistress, but I believe any structures may have been crushed.

believe: ^Six:	I believe there was some machinery inside the asteroid.
^Six:	We may have activated it inadvertently.

c: ^El:		I'm meant to find sites, not destroy them.

s: ^El: 	What kind of machinery does that?
^El:		Well, at least we found something.

g-0: ^Six:	I will consider what it might have been, Mistress, while I sleep.

c: ^Six:	Yes, Mistress. We were somewhat closer to death on this particular occasion.

s: ^El:		Did we destroy that asteroid, Six?
^El:		You think I'm close to death when I use a toaster.
c: ^Six:	Mistress, the entire asteroid collapsed on itself, crushing everything within.

g-0: ^Six:	I will power down in the corner.
^Six:	I may make occasional soft bleeps, I hope that will not disturb you.

s: ^El:		Do you have to do that?
c: ^Six:	It is a side-effect of my data processing.
^Six:	I fear I am not in control of it.

s: ^El:		It was probably your bleeps that set off that asteroid.

g-3: ^>>> I closed my eyes, and tried to sleep.

missed_job_offer: ^>>> 	Just passing was my neighbour, an old lady.

c: ^Kati:	That isn't a name, it's a curse.
^Kati:	Well while you were nowhere, I've been taking your messages.
^Kati: 	If you want to find a man, that's not the place for a girl like you.
^Kati:	If you're a woman that makes me a crone.
^Kati: 	I might as well be. Taking messages for you.
^Kati:	Don't be so gleeful. You'll be old in the end.
^Kati: 	Wait a minute. Not so fast.
^Kati: 	You don't think I'm standing out here for my health, do you?

g-0: ^Kati:	I've got a message for you.

s: ^El:		And you've been waiting here to give it to me?
c: ^Kati:	I have the young man my word, didn't I? Besides, what else would I be doing.
^Kati:	Some man. He seemed quite well-dressed to be calling on you.

s: ^El:		I doubt he was 'calling on' me.

g-1: ^Kati: 	He knocked on my door to ask if you were in. I said most likely not, if you weren't in.
^Kati: 	He asked me to give you this. Said he'd be back.
^>>> She held out a small business card.

c: ^El:		'Atlas Expeditions'. Do they want to give me a job?

s: ^El:		I don't want it, whatever it is.
c: ^Kati: 	I told him I'd give it to you, so here it is.
^Kati:	If you throw it away, that's your problem.
^Kati: 	Someone round here needs to call you by your real name.
^Kati:	You shouldn't forget where you come from.

s: ^El:		This isn't where I come from.

job_offer: ^>>> On the corridor to my room, a man in a suit was waiting.

c: ^El::	He doesn't look right for this neighbourhood.
^Rep:	All right. El. I'm glad I caught you.
^Rep:	Just back from the Sarkian Belt. You must be exhausted, so I won't keep you.

s: ^El:		Get out of my way, I'm tired.
c: ^Rep:	Been busy out in the Sarkian Belt. I quite understand.

s: ^El: 	You don't look like an archaeologist.

imfromexp: ^. I imagine you know our work.

s: ^El:		I've heard of your company, of course.
c: ^El:		Although quite what you do is something of a mystery, isn't it?

s: ^El:		Your company doesn't have the best reputation.

c: ^El:		I've had a long day and I'm very tired.
^El: 	Now go away before I'm rude.

g-2: ^Rep:	We're in much the same line of work as you. We fund people, just like you, to sail to windward and see what hasn't been found.

s: ^El:		And then you sell what you find.

b: ^Rep:	We do more than simply fence our finds, Doctor.
^Rep: 	Do you not? I'd be surprised.

s: ^El:	 	Are you here to threaten me?
c: ^El: 	Back off our turf, is that it?
^Rep:	The Delta belongs to everyone. We don't want to stand in the way of your explorations. Quite the opposite, in fact.

s: ^El:		You want to offer me a job?

funded: ^Rep:	You're funded by the university, is that right?

s: ^El:	 	I'm serious. Get out of my way or I'll call security.
c: ^El:		It'll take him a few minutes to find his stick, but I can wait.
^Rep:	All right. I won't try to persuade you.

b: ^Rep:	Did you get my card from the old lady?

c: ^Rep: If you change your mind, get in touch.
^>>> The man tapped his forehead in salute, and moved away along the corridor.

s: ^El:		I'm not going to work for you.
c: ^El:		It doesn't matter how much you pay.
^Rep:	Just hear me out, that's all I ask.

s: ^El:		Until I had to decide who to hand over my findings to.

g-0: ^Rep: 	Very well, then. The offer will stay open.

s: ^El:		Let me know where to be.

yesthanks: ^Rep:	Excellent. My employers will be most pleased.
^Rep:	And you needn't tell the university about this.

g-1: ^>>> He turned to go, then paused.
^Rep: 	Oh. One last thing. Can I ask you...
^Rep:	What are you looking for out there?

s: ^El:		You can ask, but I won't answer.
c: ^Rep:	Well. I can see we're going to get along swimmingly.
^Rep:	Not yet. Maybe one day we will be.

s: ^El:		The answer. To the real question.

c: ^El:		This whole Nebula was populated, from end to end. Now it's a few planets, a few asteroids.

s: ^El:	... 	Where did they all come from?
c: ^El:		We've found ships and buildings as old as anything out here.
^El:		Were we all born with ships?

s: ^El:		I've never seen any proof for it.
c: ^Rep:	You'd like to dig up your own bones, perhaps.

s: ^El:		That would make a convert our of anyone.

c: ^Rep:	Goodness, no. I don't make /veiled/ threats.

s: ^El:		There has to be a better explanation.
^El:		What is the Loop Hypothesis, exactly?
c: ^El:		People mention it, they way you did. Like it explains itself.
^Rep:	In a way, you have it.
^Rep:	Loopers believe the artefacts we find are the ruins of our own civilisation.
^Rep:	The past is our future and the future is our past.

s: ^El:		And where does it all come from?
c: ^Rep:	Well, there's a question for the theologians.

maybe: ^Rep:	Maybe. But the Loop is neat. And comforting.
^Rep:	We'll all live again. Why not?

b: ^Rep: In case you change your mind.
^Rep:	There's a dig tomorrow. Get in touch tomorrow and I'll send you the coordinates.
^Rep: Get in touch. There's a dig tomorrow. You could be there.

goodnight: ^>>> 	The man moved away down the corridor. I couldn't hold back a shiver.

epilogue: ^>>> Then Six finally rolled up towards me.

c: ^Six:	Apologies, Mistress, I was negotiating the stairs.

s: ^El:		I thought you were supposed to protect me?
c: ^El:		Someone jumps me from inside my room, and you're not there.
^Six: 	My apologies, Mistress. I detected no danger.
^Six: 	I was following at a distance so as not to disturb you.
^Six: 	I am relieved to hear your are unhurt, Mistress.

s: ^El: 	Your timing is just bad, that's all.
^El: 	The sooner I get you chipped, the better.
c: ^Six: 	Mistress, my Ethical Core cannot be chipped.

s: ^El:		Let's put that to the test, shall we?

b: ^El:		I think he wanted to offer me a job.
^El: 	If he wanted to threaten me, he'd have done it.

c: ^Six: 	And will you consider it, Mistress?

s: ^El:		Are you asking as a friend, or a university asset?
c: ^Six:	I cannot help being both, Mistress.

s: ^El: 	It sounds like it should be simple enough.

called_atlas: ^:: TODO talk to atlasn and get coordinate to fly ot
flashback_girl_1: ^>>> I made my first discovery aged twelve, in the slum district of Ghw on the outskirts of Elbroreth.
^§ Note this scene has no Six, and a younger version of El so let's keep it simple; even first-person..?
^§ Setting: an alley between rising slum blocks. El is on the run, having slipped out of the factory where she works. She is being chased by her foreman, a slightly older child named Chi.
^§The route is fairly linear, but turns corners, so visiblity is a little cut-off. Not being able to go backwards is not a problem, and is highly preferred, so forward-only cameras might work well.

s0: ^Chi: 	I know you're in here somewhere! I can smell you!
